author: sethmanchester
content: @hebakadry  taught my dumb ass over many years of patience that loudness is built in the mix which really shook up my workflow 8-10 years ago... that being said, after many years of working together we've recently collaborated on a few projects where I intentionally didn't take it easy on the mix bus but still encouraged her to push it further and get as creative & collaborative with the master as she wanted to. It's resulted in some of my favorite sounding records I've ever been a part of. She respected the mix, but took chances and didn't just hand me back my mix. Out the door they were some of my favorite mixes I've ever done and Heba brought something else to them that I couldn't or wouldn't have thought to. I trust her taste & I asked for her imprint. I think there's a way to do both... you can 100% encourage a mastering engineer to push things further and forward without undercooking a mix... but it definitely requires an alignment of taste and trust.

author: cian riordan
content: Ruairi fishing for deep cuts! The best experience I ever had was over a decade ago. Having spent a considerable chunk of time recording an album for & with my best friend -- we asked Eric Valentine to master the record and he said yes. Having worked under for him for a few years at this point, it felt like a bit of a reckoning... having him critically listen to something I had really poured my all into. Needless to say, he treated it as he treated everything... with genuine curiosity and actionability. He sized up the mixes in no time, told me the strengths, the weaknesses, even sent me into the other room to re-print versions slightly quieter, fix this pop here, maybe put the guitar solo up here. He gave it his full 12 hours (what felt like 100 hours to me) and the end product leveled up in so many ways. Granted he is not really a 'mastering engineer', but he approached this little project like he approached everything in his music career, with a deep sense of giving a fuck and knowing that there's no real excuse to not fix the obvious issues in front of you. The album sounded fantastic and it really spoiled me for what a mastering experience could be.

author: hebakadry
content: Hey, pretty stoked about this new plugin.  Safe to say there hasn’t been much innovation in the lathe world until this plugin came around…was checking it out a bit in the beta testing phase…for those who aren’t cutting engineers the reference edition is absolutely amazing.  You can get a general sense of how your master will sound to cut and even audition various turntables and cartridges to see how it could sound.  Better language and tools when you’re communicating with your cutting engineer as well.  It also has an amazing visual emulation so you can actually see what’s going on with your grooves.  This is such a special plugin…i don’t get behind a lot of stuff but this is pretty game changing, esp for mastering engineers that don’t cut but actually care about the translation to LP. It was developed with Helmut Erler who was at Dubplates for many years…really amazing dude and friend of mine.  He's cut some really important techno records.  I think the visualization of the cutter head and the grooves will start to make sense to a lot of people that are a bit in the dark about cutting and modulation and how program material can really affect how things sound ultimately…also how you process your master esp when it goes to plants that do in house cuts that are a bit on the safe/boring side.  You can get ahead and provide a master that counteracts some of the wide processing moves they make to avoid distortion at all cost.  Also send your client a ref of what your cut could sound esp when people push back on super long programs that don't translate well https://www.tokyodawn.net/tdr-simulathe-ref/

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Seems to me the market for people wanting to use AI mastering at the moment are those who wouldn’t (and I’d argue are not at the place to) pay a mastering engineer. They just want it to be better, and fast.

I’m with Ruairi, there will be a day that AI will be as good or “better” than almost all mastering engineers, at least in bringing things to center of bell curve. But @Barbara has it exactly right to me — mastering is just shades of “different”…we all react emotionally to different stuff

So I’ve been chewing a lot on the thought of…how can we be singular? And irreplaceable? In the mastering role, it is much more than sonics. It is communication, enthusiasm, taste, vision, patience, challenging ideas when it’s right, being open to new ones…all of it. A trusted and reliable link in the chain that ideally lets the rest of the creative team focus on what they do best.

So I’m focusing on developing a singular skill set. Part of that is sonics, sure. But there is also so much more that I think we can bring to the table. If we are singular then we matter and can add something to the art. If we just make things brighter and louder, AI is gonna beat us, and in my estimation, should.

author: Andy Lawson
content:
Just reading all the mastering/mixer chat above. In my world I am generally the one communicating with the ME (either being mixer or producer/mixer). Over time I’ve just taken to this being my roll. It definitely takes up more of my time without upfront payment but I feel that comes back to you with trust from your client.

My first listen to the master is what I try to work from. Does the song feel good? (It’s deeper than that but you get my drift). Communicate my thoughts with the artist and ask for there feedback. (I feel like me giving the thumbs up can really elevate their fears and listen freely 🤞)

Reasons for being the middle man
 1. I hopefully can communicate well with both (translating what the artist may want into actual terms) 2. Taking the stress away from the artist 3. taking stress and needless revisions away from the mastering engineer..
4.hopefully a better end product!.

That is where I’m at currently but always open to evolving

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
TLDR if vinyl is important to you (it's not to everyone and that's ok - some bands just need merch to survive)

- HIre a Mastering Engineer who understands the format, the stages of production and can QC effectively
- If you can at all hire a dedicated cutting engineer recommended by your ME over the all in package from plant
- Choose where your vinyl is pressed based on the most current info your Mastering engineer can access on who is doing mostly good work this year ("I had a great pressing from URP 3 years ago" is basically useless info)
- Be realistic about what's possible

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I have a thought for you- your mastering engineer is likely the wrong place to look for mix feedback. 

I thought a ME would be THE person to ask for feedback from  for a long time, but consider the fact that you want *them* to do *their* job well too- asking them to unpack your mix while simultaneously trying to make it work… it’s just the wrong place to go looking for feedback. 

Rather we should be looking for feedback during the mixing stage, and when it goes to master, just notice what’s different. YOU pay attention to what’s new, how they heard your shit and what they found in it.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
On the more general topic of what @macca should do (or anyone else in their situation)...I'd say just forget about mastering at all. The approaches and mindset I'm using, if you have access to the mix...makes them irrelevant IMO. I'm also sorta opinionated on this though. Like...why worry about making a tiny .3 db cut with .7 Q to clear up the vocal range....when you could just cut the actual elements that are the problem...or just raise the vocal?

And almost certainly your monitoring won't let you hear these tiny moves enough to even learn probably. But I suppose there is some value is understanding the subtle balance shifts.

For me, many people can "master" their own track just fine for where they are at. It's not helpful at all for them to learn what a pro mastering engineer is doing day-to-day if they ever are only going to be "mastering" their mix. Why? It's like saying it's useful to learn the trumpet if you're ever only going to play piano IMO. Sure, it's still music but almost no skills will actually translate across. 

You can always fix it better on an individual track than on the stereo file.

I also sorta bristle at the what is "mastering" convo...we just finish records. That's it. Whatever it takes. Of course there are some broad approaches that will be applicable to everyone, but most of them would be better forgotten by mixers so they can make bolder and more creative moves.

Again, this is all just in my opinion, perhaps Ruairi is rubbing off on me lol? (notice strategic placing of lol @Nomograph Mastering )

author: Deleted User
content:
I would recommend separating mixing and mastering into another task from composition and arrangement. 

Printing all the instrumentation before moving onto mixing process can help you separate your brain a bit too. I also usually “save as” the session and name it this way

Artist - Songtitle Mix YYYYMMDD

the challenge in doing everything yourself is splitting the brain. once you get that together, it becomes easier. Limiting the Mix process into one to three days maximum can also help overthink less. After producing, you’ve heard the song so many times and it will be very easy to start second guessing.

CLA said “a mixer’s greatest weapon is our fresh perspective”. And it’s probably the same for mastering engineers too. Switching modes takes practice, and it can’t be done without practicing it at least in my experience. What helped me personally is mixing less while producing. Not putting too much time into processing individual elements unless I know exactly what I’m doing next. I try not to troubleshoot and figure out why the mix isn’t there yet because the arrangement isn’t done yet. 

How could I possibly make the drums work with vocals if the vocals aren’t there yet?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Eh, who are these people and what does it matter to any of us what they think? Do they have any bearing on what the rest of us do? It sounds like Dave may be in a bubble of mastering engineer discourse where these advocates for massive dynamic range have an outsized voice. Clearly most of the world has moved on and don't heed the opinions of these people advocating for massive dynamic range.

Competitive loudness is a skill that we all have to learn, but people regularly push it too far and the best mixes will still crumple if they're pushed beyond their limit. Some records would have been better if people exercised restraint with how hard they push loudness. You can overcook loudness and you can undercook it as well.

As with so many things, the optimal solution is context dependent and somewhere in the middle. Neither too loud nor too quiet. You simply use your ears and do what's best for the record.

author: Halliemmelton
content: hey y'all! sorry that this is random, I'm bringing up an old convo here that I missed the first time around, regarding objectivity  vs perspective in mastering! Wanted to give a little context--i made my post about perspective mostly from the standpoint of understanding that a master does also need to have objectivity. My main motive with that post was mostly stressing the importance of getting an additional set of ears on it when possible, rather than just using the mix engineer or producer to master the project--not necessarily when budget doesn't allow the expense, but rather when the undervaluing of how a good master can serve the project prevents people from hiring an actual mastering engineer/third set of ears. My statement was kinda broad, with the intention to get attention and start conversations! also why it was prefaced as a hot take. Ruairi is absolutely right though, restraint and objectivity is the most important; I think i just didn't touch on that because hopefully, in theory, if you hire a mastering engineer, they know this and practice this. The post itself was strong-worded & also pretty nuanced but I just wanted to be clear to my mastering fellows what point I was intending to make!

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Maybe I'm a skeptic of most mastering engineers broadly but I would not want mastering rebuilding tracks. Ruairi I would trust, Randy too. Get "I run everything through 6 analog pieces standard" guy outta here. As if they have the final word on what sounds good and is musical. Almost without exception (and I've heard the A/Bs) these types tend to have bad taste.

I want the most musical people closest to the record doing it. The ones with the vision in their veins. It's better for the song. Sometimes we need to do it mastering and I will not hesitate to do so if it's pulling that way. But just listening to a lot of music the ones that come in and you can tell were built through the level and processing close to an end product, and the decisions based on that, on balance speak much more to what they are. Obviously this doesn't go for everything. Broad observation.

author: spectrummasters
content:
...so, the short answer jack is yes , the wide q eq moves are definitely advantageous and applicable outside of the mastering stage (for my workflow)....very much so. I think in a way , the broad eq is sort of like a painter taking a few steps back from the canvas having been working up close on a detailed brushstroke (which I’d suggest for example is like a surgical eq move in a mix or saturating a sound at the production stage etc).....”stepping back” and listening not just to The minutiae but the overall tone i think is a discipline that is potentially easy to forget in mix mode ......and in a sense this is how the broad EQ is serving me . I find the eq points ruairi shared work v well at the group bus stage also......for light touches

With regards to whether I’m only mastering . No, currently my most common paid work comes from local / independent artists in my network I’ve built mostly from my local community outwards through word of mouth. This is primarily in the rnb/trap/hip-hop genres and for better or worse it appears to have been normalised that when someone wants a mix....what they want is a mixter. I’m with Derek Ali’s Enginears platform and even there they are promoting a free master from us as mixers on the platform.
Personally, I’m not against certain mixers mastering as well....but i think this is more genre specific.....and also v much down to the individual. I think you spoke about your arc on here into mastering and others have too. ....i believe there is much to benefit from having professional mastering engineers, with thousands of hours under their belt listening to thousands of tracks in excellent environments......take the final listen and make the final adjustments on a mix..and for me, i consider myself on a career arc towards becoming that .

author: Slow Hand

The only thing I can think of is that when you drag the audio files into Ableton to double check that they've printed correctly you're creating a new .asd analysis file for every audio file. Maybe your ME accidentally received an .asd file where they should have received an audio file.

Then again, it sounds like you're covered since you checked on your friend's laptop. Are you sure the ME didn't receive an .asd? You would know not to upload that file, but the mastering engineer might not think to look for that if they're dragging in 30 files all at once.

You're printing in .wav or .aiff right? There shouldn't be any problem with the audio files on different OS's because audio files today are all OS agnostic and should function the same.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my side I always want to keep working with people -- you never know how the relationships evolve (I know you know this, you are more experienced than me). I just tackle the notes -- it's rare I would ever say it wasn't a great experience. I want to master as many records as I can. At the very most I would let them come back again, say it's not the right fit and suggest someone I know to be a good fit (I've done this before). But always with the art and their vision first, if I truly don't understand it.

That said -- I did get really close to walking on a recent project, we were way down a rabbit hole, I think I legitimately did 15 masters. And we were caught up on dither, comparing to pink noise, etc. It was wild. We got it across the line - but I went way out of what would be constituted by us as what the "mastering role" should say, because the music was great and I thought the artist could understand my perspective. And I think it actually hit, to refocus on the art and feeling. 

It's a fine line. Sometimes I get the impression that I do step out of what is supposed to be said by mastering engineers -- but people seem to connect with that on my side. 

Also if things are going that way I will just stream it to them -- often they are looking for control or are having a hard time making decisions -- something I see in this new crop of record makers who only have ever worked in a DAW. Hard to know without actually knowing the humans

Then again, many many times I get a note and it's great and insightful and I love it

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think there's may be an unspoken assumption here that the punch in your record is going to come from your master buss processing, when in fact you'll get more punch by balancing your mix and your arrangement.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but you're not a mastering engineer right? I gather that you're more of a producer/mixer who is trying to learn about 2-buss processing because you think that's how to make a record punchy.

While 2-buss compression can give you a little punch and impact, you're going to get 90% of your mix's punch through good balance, arrangement, and sound selection. You've got way more control over the impact of your mix by addressing these things. Not your master buss.

If you're new to this, poor or overcooked setting on your stereo buss will work against you and can turn your mix to mush.

author: Paris Lee
content:
When navigating revisions for me (had to go to a rev 3 recently with someone I’d label ‘eccentric’, and had parted ways with the original mastering engineer before me) 
I think the best practice is to always establish what you did verbally from rev to rev, being careful not getting into the weeds of ‘well you wanted me to widen but that kinda affects this and that bla bla…

don’t confuse them..! 

Don’t talk about frequencies or gain reduction numbers or LUFS etc…

Be concise and confirm you performed their notes point by point, and, get a conformation back that- did you actually accomplish what you set out to do?  To what degree? Did you nail two of the three notes? 1 of the three? 3 of 4? Or all of them? 
Whatever it is- this should help them focus and get the conversation so it’s not just them coming back with things that you weren’t even aware of what they were thinking.

author: hebakadry
content: Very quick take on the vinyl gripes some people have.  I am of the younger cutting generation and I can definitely assure you guys that cutting engineers today are way better than the nostalgia people have about cutting “back in the day”.  We have amazing tools now…plugins to manually de-ess the program material cutting engineers get from mastering engineers that have had ZERO sibilance mitigation, totally blasted material at -6LUFS with clipped transient information, distortion, you name it….we actually have tools now to fix these issues that people 20 years ago had only one knob to process it.  We even had a tiny amount of innovation on pitch computers which were last made in the early 80s.  That being said..there has been very little innovation in lathes otherwise…we are still working with lathes from 1970 or earlier because literally NO ONE has been able to improve upon the sheer magnitude of incredible feat of engineering lathe machines that Neumann and Scully made 50 years ago.  There have been kickstarters…many many dudes tried, they literally all failed.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Folks, I have a question for the group. Would love to get a mastering engineers perspective. I'm curious what is the rationale behind masters clipping output converters and leaving in true peaks that exceed 0dBFS? I get that clipping converters can sound cool / desirable, but why not achieve the clipping you want and then print a final master under zero? Why risk a consumer product crapping out during playback and adding potential distortion and why totally disregard pretty much every DSP's recommendation that true peaks not exceed -1 for the encoding process? I'm noticing that a ton of major label releases are peaking above zero with loudness normalization turned off on Spotify.

author: Zack Hames
content:
That said - at the level that you, Matt, Cian, Jon, and every other person who’s been on the live, youre not getting completely fucked mixes.

A lot of us still get mixes or recordings that are not fully realized. I know some people in here have said they’d never edit or tune what they were given to mix. There was a time that’s what I spent the majority of my time doing because it was unlistenable until I did. (Happens less and less now 🙂 ) #
I mastered a track recently, the vocal reverb was so whack. They didn’t EQ the reverb at all, it was insanely sibilant just in the reverb, etc. you guys know what I’m talking about. The artist mixed it themself and they’re NOT a mixer, so I kindly prodded and got her to EQ it out. She was thankful and it made it significantly better. 

Also, I did use compression on the bus on that master - but I would never expect a mastering engineer to put that on my mix because I’m compressing my mix already.  

Mixing pop, mixing well produced tracks from seasoned folks who make decisions well before the mixer is involved, is way different than mixing a local bands home recorded ep. Both need totally different perspectives and tools and focuses.

This got derailed…point is, my view on mastering’s role has changed dramatically since listening to LWMR. I hope I never have to “master” my own own mixes again because  I think it’s fundamentally, in some ways, not even truly mastering.

That’s an extreme black/white example, but I’ve got some big life changes coming and I’m really trying to reevaluate where my time is best spent and how it relates to my long term goals.

You and Ruairi straddle two very specific and niche worlds so was just looking for insight on how you handle your balance! How specific are you with your time management when you go down rabbit holes? And how that relates to your mastering goals

author: matthewrederburg
content:
I have a silly question for all the mastering engineers out there. Is it bad form to hire a ME to work on material that will never see a release?

The majority of my current work is recording/mixing live sessions for a radio station, an endeavor that has no budget or consideration for the mastering stage. I’m looking to build a relationship with a mastering engineer and it would be well worth it for me to pay for a few masters myself, in lieu of any actual client, in order to find a mastering engineer that I like.

The mixes sent will likely be from my work on these live sessions. It’s contractually fine for me to send this material for mastering, but nobody is asking for it and therefore none of the mastered material will be released.

tl;dr I want to pay professionals for services but I’m worried that the context is weird. Am I good?

author: matthewrederburg
content:
I freelance outside of my radio job. These projects are more likely to make it to mastering. My work history leaves me unable to recommend a mastering engineer to clients when they ask, and I'm looking to change that.

The radio recordings go like this:

1. Record artist performing live
2. Edit and mix for broadcast
3. Sessions gets broadcast. This is the primary "release" of the material
4. Copies of lossless mixes get sent to artist after broadcast. They do with them what they like, including the possibility of release. My involvement here amounts to no more than a credit.

I mention these radio recordings because they represent the bulk of my recent work, and they happen within a fixed process with no consideration for mastering. I started this job without a working relationship with a ME, and the scope of these sessions don't enable me to ever send my work to mastering engineers. Nobody is paying for it basically. I'd love to though!

To answer your question @Nomograph Mastering , the material sent for mastering would have already reached all of its expected stages of release. I would only be hiring a mastering engineer to work on it so I may hear their work. The mastering is for me, not the radio station or the artist - it just so happens that these live session mixes are the most frequent and current projects I work on.

It's a weird situation and that's why I ask the question. I'd just like to be able to recommend a ME to future enquiring clients, and seeing as I have no recent history with any mastering engineer, hiring them to work on the material I have seemed like the best way to get to know their work.

Whew. Appreciate your time. That was really hard to chew through for some reason.

author: sethearnest
content:
Question to the mastering minds on here from a mixer who has to self-master often: when pushing a solo piano (or piano-focused arrangement) into 'very loud' territory, limiters seem especially sensitive to pianos and get to crackling faster than with most any other instrument. 

My thoughts as to why: 
1) the inherent dynamic range of the instrument (attack vs sustain of it)
2) The amount of midrange frequency build up inherent to the instrument and overtones created
3) Often, the music styles I'm referring to will be orchestral or film score ish, so any amount of distortion is noticed more quickly than the natural masking that can occur in something like a rock track

FF ProL2 seems especially sensitive to pianos, and I'll often reach for something else when it's a piano-heavy arrangement.

Is there something else I'm not thinking about in this area? 

(This is all under the umbrella of knowing how to do loud well w/the understanding that often times our solo piano Icaruses don't need get that close to the sun, and I can just back it off a couple dB. I'm just trying to understand why limiters seem to fall apart so quickly specifically w/pianos.)

author: hebakadry
content: 1. more dynamics, 2. treated sibilance, 3. shorter sides, and 4. smarter sequencing…those are all good things to know about.  And if you’re at the forefront of that as a mastering engineer you will certainly have a better sounding cut, especially if you make very informed decisions about where it’s cut, plated and sometimes bargaining with the label about where it’s pressed.  It empowers the artist to know they have some control on how their LP will sound instead of just throwing hands up in the air and saying modern vinyl sucks, which is not true.

author: Reedy
content:
Reading this has reminded me of a horror story I had earlier this year with a client / mastering engineer. It's hardly relevant but I'd like to share it as it's public forum and I'm curious if other people have gone through similar experiences. 
I said to client I could master the record, they said they had read online that the mixer should never master the record and to get a different mastering engineer. I said sure, but I would be happy to give them a test master to compare against the master from the engineer. Sent it off to mastering with the mix, test master and stems for stem mastering. Mastering engineer came back and had *completely changed the character of the record*. Did not sound like the mix I had done and definitely didn't sound like the test master I had done (which was mainly a louder version of the mix). Fine if it doesn't sound like the test master, but not fine if it didn't sound like the mix. We must have sent it back to this guy 3 times and every time it returned the same wildly different character. I told artist let me have another go at the mastering, they agreed and I did another master. All was good until the client brought it into their car and apparently there was something really wrong with the master... To this day I still don't know what exactly was wrong, I tested and tested and did absolutely everything I could to eliminate the problem the artist was talking about, but I couldn't hear the problem they were talking about and every time I changed stuff and sent it back to them to test, the main issue at hand was still there. In the end, they went with the mastering engineer's master. I didn't care that they went with someone else, I cared that my mix work was undone and I went above and beyond to try and repair it and it was all for nothing. Kick in the teeth is that it wasn't really that great a record either and I did far too much work for something I should have declined to work on in the first place.

author: Reedy
content: To add, it was wasn't clear if the mastering engineer did a stem master or mastered the mix, he never said... But I'm gonna go with it was a stems master. (I only provided the stems because the artist asked me to send it because the mastering engineer told him to do it).

author: aidanthillmann
content:
Hi, I’m not a mastering engineer but I did a sort of mastering experiment recently:

I was watching the Mix with the Masters videos with Randy Merrill and Idania Valencia, and I noticed that they were using plain old input gain before their limiter to push it instead of increasing the threshold of the limiter itself, so their limiter thresholds/gains were at 0. I thought maybe they knew something I didn’t.

So I tried it. I put a gain plugin before my limiter and pushed the limiter with it. The results? It sounds awful. All the punch and width is gone. Change back to using the limiter’s threshold, sounds great.

Any technical reason for this? I was using the Kilohearts Gain plugin in to Ozone Maximizer, but I would be hard pressed if it was one of those plugins at fault. Maybe the threshold of the limiter has an internal signal flow that changes its behavior as opposed to gain coming in to it or something? Maybe this workflow makes better sense in Sequoia for the Sterling engineers for some reason?

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Hey there how's it going!

Just wanted your thoughts on advice on something I'm currently trying to tackle with my own mastering buisness.

Currently on my 2nd year, and at the moment I'm contacting lots of UK dance/electronic labels to try get some consistent work coming in. All is well until the majority of labels I contact all get mastered by the same engineer who charges £10 a track, which I think is such a low rate and seems like a race to the bottom.

Is it worth it at my stage to take on these lower paying gigs? 

My thoughts are:
- It could be damaging to the clients I already work with that pay my full rate.
- These bottom clients will never be full rate if they've had a £10 deal for years
- It gets more work in for me = my name gets spread out a bit more. But, these labels never seem to credit the mastering engineer.

What are your thoughts? What would you do?

author: Will Pragnell
content: For mastering projects with more than just one or two tracks, what are folks thoughts on delivering one track before doing the rest, vs the whole lot at once? Thinking about this from the perspective of the client and how it makes them feel and could add / remove confidence. On one side, it gives them an early indication of direction and an early opportunity to give feedback, which some may enjoy. On the other, it could communicate less confidence on the part of the mastering engineer, and I feel like a big part of what we are trying to do here is make them feel confident about releasing the record. Found myself wondering about this over my morning coffee... anyone thought about this much?

author: Will Pragnell
content:
Great question. Let me try to answer. I suspect this may be where the learning opportunity lies...

I think what matters to me is that 1) the piece is presented in the best way possible to maximise its impact or essence 2) the piece is listenable and that impact is not lost in a wide range of environments / contexts (i was tempted to say "it translates well" but I think that's a subtly different thing) 3) the client is happy with the result, and feel confident releasing their art, feeling good about it, feeling it's the best version of what it could be.

I think it's point 3 that gives me pause. You can count my paying mastering clients on one hand, so I'm as "beginner level" as it gets, but that said, when i talk to those clients, they share with me that they want a mastering engineer to ensure that their music is going to "sound right on streaming platforms and translate well to lots of systems". There's a lot of FUD about loudness normalisation, LUFS, etc. I don't think it's a huge leap to feel that we should also be thinking about common playback devices such as airpods, and bluetooth speakers. For clients who aren't seasoned mixers or record makers, I wonder how they would feel if they listened to their mastered record on a bluetooth speaker and heard that whole parts had practically vanished. Of course I'm also sensitive to not wanting to introduce doubt in their minds unnecessarily.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content:
Vinyl mastering question from a complete vinyl noob - what's the overall process? I've always passed off vinyl to other mastering engineers when it comes up for a project I've mastered but I've just been asked for "vinyl ready masters".

What's the process usually like? I would prepare files with attention paid to bottom/top end which then get sent to an engineer with a lathe? Do they do any subsequent processing? Or do I submit just the regular digital masters and they handle everything?

author: Elaine Rasnake
content:
Generally when I've had to master files for someone to press to vinyl, I will take the limiter off and create  designated A side / B Side files along with a PQ sheet of all of the start/stop times, album order, and things like that via HOFA DDP Maker.
I leave all of the high end low end adjustments to the pressing engineer since they will know best what needs to be adjusted, if at all. 

I know of some folks who also just send the limited "digital distro" files but I prefer to give a more dynamic version and the pressing engineer can adjust it.

Usually an artist will go through test pressings and if there are issues, usually (or at least ideally) the pressing engineer, the artist, and the mastering engineer are all communicating about things and next steps

author: Elaine Rasnake
content: Usually the mastering engineer that made the digital distro files will also provide the vinyl pre-master side a/b files

author: Grover
content:
If that much limiting is happening then sure, it's part of the music. My experience is mainly with two situations:

1. The digital mastering engineer is the same as the cutting engineer. Artists were not bypassed in getting the vinyl cut approved. They listened to and signed off on both. 

2. The digital and cutting engineer were working closely together. 

Now, a lot of these artists were not making music that required massive amounts of limiting to sound the way they do. 

That said, I disagree. Vinyl is already changing the sound so radically that if sonic faithfulness to the digital master is required - why make vinyl? A record will NEVER sound like the digital original or even the tape master for that matter. No two lathes sound anything alike, and the differences can be astonishing. I have heard a lathe amp turn a wretched sounding track into a brilliant one. And vice versa. Vinyl is an unfaithful medium. If you don't care about the cut's sound that's fine. Submit whatever is submitted for the digital master and let the pressing house sort it out. Why even bother with a proper 3rd party cutting engineer at that point?

author: Grover
content: I suppose the philosophy as I understand is that the vinyl cutting engineer is much like the digital mastering engineer. Trying to preserve as faithfully as possible, but also dealing with the fact that they will have to alter the sound.

author: Grover
content:
That was kind of my point, my (and only my) understanding of mastering is "do no harm." I produce and write quite a bit too and I'd be a little cross if a mastering engineer was mucking about making massive changes. If an artist and team have made choruses 3dB louder than verses for example, and 3dB or more of limiting is in place, is it appropriate for the mastering engineer to turn up the verses? Sometimes that's what is needed to achieve loudness. My question is less about whether loudness is the goal and more an attempt to describe the philosophy that I was taught, as I understand it. 

I think we're saying the same thing?

author: cian riordan
content: I’m not sure what you’re saying! I guess I’m saying that there are mastering engineers that will hem and haw and try to change what’s in place by peeling back limiting or making changes that change the overall composition and density of the song… and then there are the ones that I want to hire.

author: Grover
content: I'm not sure what "peeling back limiting" means exactly. But I would say that if the client asks for -9LUFS then that is the job, to make it -9LUFS. If they want -14LUFS then that is the job. And in doing so only to pass through as transparently as possible what the creative team has done. The challenging part in mastering is that at a very minute level all of the tools a mastering engineer has do affect the sound. The skillful balance thereof is what makes the craft fascinating fun and challenging. I suppose I was a bit caught off guard by Nomograph's positing that heavy limiting at the mastering stage to affect the groove (maybe I misunderstood that comment) is pretty much the standard. I don't find that much limiting to be very transparent personally. Doesn't make it wrong. clients are free to work with whomever does work they like best, as you say.

author: Grover
content:
sure of course. I guess personally find it a little outside my experience for a mastering engineer to use limiters to get a tone or style though. 
I guess I also don't understand how a mastering engineer can or would want to undo limiting at the mix stage if they're working with a stereo file that's already been mixed...

author: Grover
content: ahhhh. I was only referring to the final output limiter/clipper that the mastering engineer puts in place when targeting digital loudness. The cutting engineer will just turn your master down if you submit a clipped/heavily limited master.

content: Ruairi is a north star for me because he can move silently as needed or slap an infundibulum on something too. Which is what I aim for as wel and think that's what the best mastering engineers can do. Follow the song

author: Rollmottle
content: You could position it by saying you typically work with mastering engineers who you've built working relationships with, who know you, how you mix, what you prefer, etc and it will likely result in a better outcome than you working with somebody you don't know.

author: hebakadry
content: Also worth noting, it’s very very common in Europe, especially in the dance/electronic scene…some mastering engineers I really respect do it all the time like Rashad, Zino & Enyang with excellent results.
